User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; de; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13
Build Identifier: 1.0b2

The authentication information, at least the password, is no longer used by lightning 1.0b2 to access a remote ical/webdav resource. Instead, an authentication dialog is prompted. Checking the checkbox to store the information again does not help. In the stored passwords list the information is still available. Happens on Linux and Windows, no info about other OS. No master password used.

First occured with the latest thunderbird/lightning update.

The dialog pops up every some minutes, I think, every time when lightning reloads the calendars.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a https webdav, password protected, with ics file on and use this in thunderbird/lightning.
2. Have auth information stored (don't know if a _first_ saving by this release helps, deleting the stored password doesn't help).
3. Start thunderbird.

Actual Results:  
Auth info will be requested. Should not, since it's saved.

Expected Results:  
Saved password should be used. Checking the checkbox to store auth info should also work, but I'm not sure if it does or if just the usage of the information is broken.

Nothing special with my installation, tested on Ubuntu 10.04 64bit and Windows XP.
comments.author: chris.spacelab@gmx.net

comments.text: Chris, is this still an issue using the recently released Lightning 1.0?
comments.author: mschroeder@mozilla.x-home.org
comments.raw_text: Chris, is this still an issue using the recently released Lightning 1.0?

Sorry for being that late with my answer!

Yes, it is, but the behavior becomes more and more weird with every update (either Lightning or Thunderbird): there are weeks with no problem, and suddenly, the credentials are lost every 30 minutes (or whatever the calendar update period is) for one or two days, followed again by days or even weeks with no problems. Both on windows and linux. Since I know now that someone cares, I'll try to protocol the behavior during the next weeks.

Regards, Chris
